BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. Numerous moist and wet avalanches are possible as the snowfall level rises.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Medium-sized and large natural avalanches are likely, in particular in case of releases originating from steep starting zones above approximately 2500 m. In the typical avalanche paths in particular in the regions with a lot of snow they can reach a very long way. In their paths avalanches can entrain the wet snow.
In particular below approximately 2400 m: As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible at any time, in particular medium-sized ones.
In the last few days sometimes large wind slabs formed at high altitude. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches. In some places avalanches can also penetrate down to the ground and reach large size in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
The current avalanche situation calls for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sleet gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack below approximately 2300 m. As a consequence of sleet the strong westerly wind, the snowpack could not consolidate during the last few days. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in particular on northwest to east to south facing aspects. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. Below the tree line only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Once the precipitation has ended, the avalanche activity will gradually decrease.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Occasionally large natural avalanches are likely. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular above approximately 2500 m. In their paths avalanches can entrain the wet snow. In the typical avalanche paths in particular in the regions with a lot of snow they can reach as far as the valley bottom.

In particular below approximately 2400 m: As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible at any time, in particular medium-sized ones.

As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, large wind slabs formed above the tree line. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep north, east and south facing slopes. The conditions are dangerous for ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area there is more snow than usual.
Until Tuesday the wind will be moderate to strong at times.
Monday: 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2500 m.
The rain gave rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2400 m.
The sleet gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m.
Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on steep, little used shady slopes. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The sometimes large wind slabs are prone to triggering in all aspects. Caution is to be exercised in particular above approximately 2200 m, as well as in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Avalanches can be released easily and reach medium size. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. Shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack can indicate the danger.

There is a danger of gliding avalanches and moist snow slides. This applies on steep slopes below approximately 2400 m.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep slopes above approximately 2200 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some localities up to 10 cm of snow will fall above approximately 2000 m. The wind will be moderate to strong. As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from westerly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs formed. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2200 m. The weather conditions will give rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall over a wide area. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular along the border with Switzerland and in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 4 (high) heavy snowfall above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind dry avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. In the typical avalanche paths in particular in the regions with a lot of snow they can reach as far as the valley bottom. In their paths avalanches can entrain the wet snow.
In particular below approximately 2400 m: As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible at any time, in particular medium-sized ones.

As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, large wind slabs formed above the tree line. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep north, east and south facing slopes. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. The conditions are sometimes critical for ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking outside marked and open pistes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Monday: 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2500 m.
Until Tuesday the wind will be moderate at times.
The rain gave rise to rapid and thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2400 m. The sleet gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m.
Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on steep, little used shady slopes. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger, especially at high altitude and in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 4 (high).
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes deep wind slabs formed above the tree line. These can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, in particular on north to east to south facing aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In some places avalanches can be released in deep layers of the snowpack and reach quite a large size.
In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and the danger is greater.
As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually, in the regions exposed to rain in particular. The current avalanche situation calls for caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sleet gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack below approximately 2300 m. As a consequence of sleet the strong westerly wind, the snowpack could not consolidate during the last few days. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in particular on northwest to east to south facing aspects. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. Below the tree line only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Once the precipitation has ended, the natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible at any time, but they will be mostly small.
As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes deep wind slabs formed at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep north, east and south facing slopes. In particular in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Careful route selection is advisable.
Several small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized natural dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and strong wind, in particular above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow has fallen since yesterday above approximately 2500 m.
In all altitude zones only a little snow is now lying. The snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger. The danger of moist and wet avalanches will already exist in the early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As the snowfall level rises small to medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible. The sometimes avalanche-prone wind slabs of the last few days can be released even by a single winter sport participant on very steep shady slopes and generally in high Alpine regions. In particular in regions exposed to heavier precipitation and at high altitude these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised as well in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones only a little snow is now lying. The snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong crust. The avalanche prone locations are rare. The sleet gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack below approximately 2300 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Up to the tree line and above rain will fall. Also at high altitude more moist and wet avalanches are possible until the temperature drops.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering above approximately 2400 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Sometimes the avalanches in these regions are medium-sized.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow has fallen in some localities.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust below approximately 2600 m. The old snowpack is largely stable. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
Below approximately 2400 m from a snow sport perspective, insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will cause a gradual settling of the snow drift accumulations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The soft wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on near-ridge shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs of Sunday must be evaluated with care and prudence especially on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of low temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack consolidated. The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs represent the main danger. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2200 m.
Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sometimes storm force wind has transported the loosely bonded old snow. The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and generally at high altitudes. Wind slabs are mostly easy to recognise are to be assessed with care and prudence. Avalanche prone weak layers exist in the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are prone to triggering in particular on northwest to north to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2200 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized and can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
Until the temperature falls individual small to medium-sized gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some localities 2 to 5 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 2000 m. In particular at intermediate and high altitudes the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. This applies especially in the regions with a lot of snow. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
The sleet will give rise to softening of the snowpack in some cases.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. The weather conditions will foster a slight settling of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger, especially along the border with France. As the day progresses as a consequence of warming there will be only a slight increase in the danger of dry and moist avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the last few days sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in high Alpine regions. The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can still be released in some cases especially on north to east to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are to be avoided in particular in very steep terrain.
In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
Slight increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying. Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust. Towards its base, the snowpack is moist. The sleet gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack below approximately 2300 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild. The weather conditions will foster a gradual stabilisation of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are prone to triggering in particular on northwest to north to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2200 m. Mostly avalanches are medium-sized and can be released even by a single winter sport participant. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

On steep slopes small to medium-sized gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible below approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of the strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. This applies especially in the regions with a lot of snow. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
The weather conditions will give rise to softening of the snowpack in some cases at low and intermediate altitudes.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. The weather conditions will foster a gradual settling of the snow drift accumulations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering above approximately 2400 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In some cases avalanches are medium-sized.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The old snowpack is largely stable. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust below approximately 2600 m. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.

From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will cause a gradual settling of the snow drift accumulations.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanches can in isolated cases be released, in particular by large loads. This applies in particular on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes, and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. Wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: A little snow is lying. Wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and at elevated altitudes. They are mostly small.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanches can in isolated cases be released, in particular by large loads. This applies in particular on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes, and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. Wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: A little snow is lying. Wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and at elevated altitudes. They are mostly small.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Low, level 1.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will soften quickly. Isolated small avalanches are possible in isolated cases. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and on shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains generally subject to considerable local variations. Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls mostly small wind slabs formed. As a consequence of rising temperatures the snowpack can not consolidate.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and wet snow represent the main danger. As the day progresses as a consequence of warming there will be only a slight increase in the danger of moist snow slides.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the last few days small wind slabs formed in high Alpine regions. The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can still be released in some cases especially on north to east to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2400 m.
In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling here.
Slight increase in danger of gliding avalanches and snow slides as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying. Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust. Towards its base, the snowpack is moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be very mild. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be generally stable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow is lying on top of a quite favourable old snowpack in all aspects above approximately 400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack is fairly homogeneous and has a loosely bonded surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads,.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in the high Alpine regions. Wind slabs are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind has transported only a little snow. The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and generally at high altitudes. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are shallow.
